title: The Role of Reputation and Corruption in Procurement
descriptions:
Title: The Role of Reputation and Corruption in Procurement

This grant proposal seeks funding for a comprehensive research project examining the interplay between reputation and corruption in public procurement across multiple sectors, including defense, transportation, education, and healthcare. The project consists of three empirical components, each focusing on a distinct aspect of procurement: the use of reputation in contract procurement, corruption in public procurement, and healthcare procurement regulations. 

The primary design goals of this project are to avoid waste, enhance social welfare, prevent corruption, and ensure contractor compliance. By investigating the impacts of vendor rating systems, analyzing the effectiveness of awarding rules against corruption, and evaluating the effects of discretionary awarding rules on corruption and reputation, this research aims to contribute to the development of more efficient and transparent procurement processes.

The expected outcomes of this project include improved contractor performance, reduced procurement costs, and enhanced patient welfare in the healthcare sector. Ultimately, this research will provide valuable insights into the complex relationships between reputation, corruption, and procurement, informing evidence-based policies to promote integrity and fairness in public contracting.
